title: Chapter 1 – Python Hacker Checkpoint
description: Quick concept-check for chapter 1. Use this to see what your brain picked up about Python, code vs programming, and REPL vs script mode.

questions.prompt: You want to teach a computer to send you a reminder every day at 7pm. What is a programming language in this situation?

options.label: A language spoken by humans, like English or French
A special language for writing instructions that computers can follow
A type of computer hardware (like the keyboard or mouse)
A computer operating system, like Windows or macOS

explanations.overview: A programming language is how you give precise instructions to a computer.

byOptionId.human-language: Human languages are for talking to people, not directly to computers.
byOptionId.computer-instructions: Correct – it's the language you use to write code the computer understands.
byOptionId.hardware: Hardware is the physical stuff (keyboard, mouse, CPU), not the language.
byOptionId.os: An operating system is software that manages hardware and apps, not the language you write programs in.

questions.prompt: You are designing a small game that says hello to the player. Which option best describes the difference between **programming** and **code**?

options.label: There is no real difference – people just use different words.
Code is planning the steps, programming is typing the exact instructions.
Programming includes planning and designing your game, and code is the exact Python instructions you write.
Programming is only for experts, code is for beginners.

explanations.overview: Programming is the big-picture process; code is the specific text you give the computer.

byOptionId.no-difference: There is a difference! Programming is the whole process, not just typing.
byOptionId.reversed-definition: This flips it: planning is programming, not code.
byOptionId.correct-definition: Correct – think of programming as the plan plus the code together.
byOptionId.experts-only: Anyone can learn programming; it's not just for experts.

questions.prompt: You press a big BUILD button and your code turns into an .exe file you can run over and over. What kind of language are you most likely using?

explanations.overview: C++ is a compiled language: code is translated into machine code before it runs.

byOptionId.python: Python is usually interpreted, not compiled like this.
byOptionId.cpp: Correct – C++ programs are normally compiled into executables.
byOptionId.javascript: JavaScript is typically interpreted by the browser.
byOptionId.html: HTML is a markup language for structuring web pages, not a compiled programming language.

questions.prompt: You open a Python console and type `1 + 2`, then press Enter and see `3`. This is happening in the REPL. What does **REPL** stand for?

explanations.overview: REPL describes the cycle of interactive mode: read your input, evaluate it, print the result, and loop.

byOptionId.read-eval-print-loop: Correct – this is the full name of REPL.
byOptionId.run-edit-print-load: Close-sounding, but not the official meaning.
byOptionId.read-execute-print-learn: Nice idea, but not what REPL stands for.
byOptionId.repeat-eval-print-loop: Has some of the right words, but the first step is READ, not REPEAT.

questions.prompt: Python was created in the late 1980s. Who started this whole thing?

explanations.overview: Guido van Rossum created Python and made it friendly enough for beginners and powerful enough for pros.

byOptionId.dennis-ritchie: Dennis Ritchie created the C programming language.

questions.prompt: Why is the Python language called "Python"? (No, it's not just about snakes.)

options.label: It is named after a snake because the creator liked reptiles.
It is named after the creator's pet.
It is named after a British comedy series called "Monty Python's Flying Circus".
It is an acronym for something secret and technical.

explanations.overview: Python is named after the comedy show "Monty Python's Flying Circus".

byOptionId.snake: There is a snake named python, but the language name comes from the TV show.
byOptionId.pet: Python is not named after a pet.
byOptionId.monty-python: Correct – the creator wanted a fun name.
byOptionId.acronym: Python is not an acronym; it doesn't secretly stand for something.

questions.prompt: You are saving your first hacker script so you can run it again later. Which file extension should you use for a Python file?

explanations.overview: Python scripts use the .py file extension.

byOptionId.txt: .txt is for plain text files; Python code won't be recognized as a script there.
byOptionId.exe: .exe is for compiled executables, not source code.
byOptionId.py: Correct – .py is the standard extension for Python source files.
byOptionId.java: .java is for Java source files, not Python.

questions.prompt:
Look at this line of Python code:

```python
print("Hello, World!")
```

What does the computer actually show when you run this line?

explanations.overview: The `print` function outputs exactly what is inside the quotes.

byOptionId.hello-world-no-punct: The output includes a comma and an exclamation mark: `Hello, World!`.
byOptionId.prints-code: That's the code itself, not what appears when it runs.
byOptionId.hello-world-with-punct: Correct – `print` sends this text to the screen.
byOptionId.error: There is no error here; this is valid Python.

questions.prompt: You want to quickly test what `10 / 3` does in Python, and you don't care about saving it. Which mode is the better choice?

options.label: Script mode (saving it in a .py file first)
Typing it into a text editor and never running it
Putting it into a spreadsheet cell

explanations.overview: The REPL is perfect for quick experiments like this.

byOptionId.repl: Correct – interactive mode lets you try `10 / 3` in one line and instantly see the result.
byOptionId.script: You *could* do this in a script, but it's slower for tiny tests you don't need to save.
byOptionId.text-editor: Just typing it in a text file doesn't make Python actually run it.
byOptionId.spreadsheet: Python code belongs in Python, not in a spreadsheet cell.

questions.prompt:
A friend writes this line and it crashes:

```python
print("Hello, World!)
```

What is the main problem?

options.label: One of the quotation marks is missing.
There should be a comma after print.
There should be a space after Hello.
The word World is not allowed in Python.

explanations.overview: Strings in Python need matching opening and closing quotes.

byOptionId.missing-quote: Correct – the closing quote after the `!` is missing.
byOptionId.missing-comma: You don't put a comma after `print` in this version of Python.
byOptionId.missing-space: Spaces inside the string are fine; that wouldn't crash the program.
byOptionId.wrong-word: `World` is just text inside the string; Python doesn't care what human words you use there.

questions.prompt: You want to build a small "hello" program. Which of these actions is an example of **programming** (not just code)?

options.label: Writing a list of steps like: ask for a name, then say hello, then maybe add more features later.
Clicking the Run button to see the output.

explanations.overview: Programming includes planning what the program should do before or while you write code.

byOptionId.write-print-line: That's writing actual code, not planning steps.
byOptionId.plan-steps: Correct – creating the step-by-step plan is programming.
byOptionId.save-file: Saving the file is important, but it's not really programming or code by itself.
byOptionId.run-program: Running the program tests your code, but it's not the planning part.
